ROBERT UPSALL . I produce the affidavit—the prisoner came with a person, and stated that the duplicates were lost—they had the property.
JOHN LANGLEY . I went with the prisoner to pawn the four last pieces, on the 14th of June.
NOT GUILTY .

1314.
EMMA HASSEL was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of May, 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 9d., the goods of
William Champion.

JAMES STEPHENSON . I am in the employ of William Champion. On the 15th of May, the prisoner and her elder sister came into the shop about twelve o'clock—they asked to look at some stays—they then asked to look at some shoes—I shewed them some—the prisoner, who was at the other side of the shop, came to the counter where I was shewing the other the shoes—she took three pairs and put them on the ground, and in about five minutes she put them on the counter—she then put one pair under her shawl, and said to the other, "Come, make haste"—the other female then said, she would have one pair, and gave me 3d. in halfpence, and a half-crown, and told me to give her a shilling—they then left the shop; I followed and brought the prisoner back—I found the shoes under her left arm.

Cross-examined by MR. OTTER. Q. Did not the prisoner stoop down to try on shoe? A. Yes; and when I turned, she stood up—she tried three pairs—they bad got out of the shop before I took her, and were walking away—I had the shoes on the counter in a pile—she did not give the shoes up to me—I took them from under her arm—when I brought her back, she said she had told her sister to pay for them, but she had not.
Prisoner. I tried on three or four pairs, which he gave me to try, and I said to my sister, "I have a pair; pay for them."

SARAH HASSELL . I am the prisoner's sister. I went with her to the shop—she had one pair of shoes, and as we were coming out of the shop, she asked me if I had paid for them; I said, "O dear no"—we were not out of the shop, she was behind me—she had them outside her shawl.
NOT GUILTY .

1315.
WILLIAM CRATHERN was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of December, 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1l.; 1 seal, value 10s.; 1 jacket, value 7s.; and 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Henry Hadley.

HENRY HADLEY . I live at Barking, in Essex, and am a shipwright. On the 23rd of December I was at Blackwall—the prisoner, whom I had known about two years, came to see me at ten o'clock at night—I was in bed—I got up, and got him some porter and gin—we went out and got it—we came home about twelve o'clock—we had supper, and went to bed—my watch was hanging at the head of the bed—I had wound it up at nine o'clock, when I went to bed the first time—there were two children in the room with us; one about six, and the other about ten years old—I awoke in the morning about five o'clock—the prisoner was then gone, and my watch and seal—the two children were in bed and asleep—I am convinced no one had been in the room but the prisoner—I did not see him again until last Saturday, when he was apprehended—I lost a jacket and a pair of shoes also—this is my watch, chain, and seal.
EDMUND NORTH . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this watch—it was taken in pawn of a woman on the 24th of December—she gave her name as Mary Wakeley—this is the duplicate I gave for it.

JAMES MORGAN . I am inspector of th'e police. I went to No. 5, Russell-street, Ball's-pond—I found this duplicate there, and the prisoner's wife—the prisoner acknowledged she was his wife, and said she was worse than him, for she pawned the watch.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1316.
RICHARD HENLEY and
HENRY HENLEY were Indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April, 9 chairs, value 11l. 11s., the goods of
Harriet Augusta Tanner.

Richard Henley pleaded
GUILTY . †—Aged 19.

HARRIET AUGUSTA TANNER . I live in New-street, City-road, and am a widow. I occasionally employ the prisoner Henry—on the 21st of April, I sent him for a truck—there was a large easy chair placed on it—I told him to follow me with it to Cheapside, where we took eight dining-room chairs in the truck—we then went on to High-street, St. Giles's—I then went into a house, and when I came out I saw the prisoner turn into Oxford-street—I followed, and could not see him—I inquired of a police
man, but could not hear of him—I took an omnibus, thinking I should find him, but I did not—I returned home at half-past four o'clock—he had not come—I gave directions to the police, at eight o'clock; and the next morning a policeman took me to where I found the chairs had been sold—I manufacture furniture, but do not keep a shop.
WILLIAM SMITH . I live at No. 94, York-street, Westminster. On the 21st of April, the prisoner, Richard, came between three and four

o'clock in the afternoon, with these nine chairs on a truck—he asked me to buy them, which I did, for 6l.—I can order them, and get them for 7l.—I could buy this arm-chair for 50s., and these other eight for 4l. 10s.—they are Honduras wood.
Prisoner. I went along Cheapside, and then up to Oxford-street—I then missed my mistress—I went back to see for her, and when I returned the truck was gone.
(Frederick Henry Brown, the prosecutirx's brother, gave the prisoner a good character.)

RICHARD HENLEY—
GUILTY. † Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy

by the Prosecutrix.—Both
Transported for Seven Years.

1317.
JEREMIAH KELLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of May, 8lbs. weight of lead, value 1s. 4d., the goods of
John Travers, his master.

JOHN TRAVERS . The prisoner was in my employ from fifteen to eigh
teen years, at the Repository, in Gray's-inn-lane, where I had a great quantity of lead, which had been taken off some buildings—I have com
pared this lead with some that remained on a building at St. Pancras—I believe it is part of it—it is worth 1s. 4d.

Prisoner. I was coming home over Blackfriars-bridge, and I saw one of the men with a basket—I put my hand to it and said, "What have you got here?"—he said, a bit of lead, and did I know any place where it could be sold—I said, I would have nothing to do with it—we came on to Red Lion-street, and he said, "Is there any old iron shop here?"—I said, "Yes"—we went into a shop; the gentleman came out and said, "What have you got?"—we both said "A bit of lead"—the man took it out of the basket, and put it into the scale.

THOMAS WILLIAM PIGGOTT . I keep the shop. On the 13th of May, the prisoner and another man brought the lead—the other man had it in a basket—the prisoner said, "We have got a bit of pigeon for you"—the man then put the lead into the scale—I examined it; it weighed eight pounds—I questioned them where they lived—the other man gave his name and address; the prisoner gave a false name—I then said, "I shall stop this"—the prisoner instantly ran out of the shop, and the other followed him—I watched them into a house, and sent the officer.

Prisoner. Q. Who spoke the first word? A. You did: I can not tell who gave the first name; the other gave hit name as Patrick Depy—the prisoner gave a fictitious name; not the one he gave at the station-house—he said he had cut it off some lead at Battle-bridge—I inquired who his master was—he said Mr. Travers—I said, "Why did you take it from there, you knew it was not your property"—he said his master had plenty of money, and he allowed them no beer, and they cut it off for that purpose.
Prisoner. Q. Did you ask me if there was any more there? A. No; but you told me there were twelve or fifteen tons there, and said that piece could not be missed.

WILLIAM CHICHESTER REYNOLDS (police-constable M 119.) I saw the prisoner running—I went and took him—he had been up a chimney, and was covered with soot—he said he was sorry, for his master was a good master.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 37.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury—his master

div1.p:
promised to employ him.—
Confined Eight Days.

1318.
WILLIAM WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of May, 5 shirts, value 1l. 2s.; 2 tippets, value 2s.; 1 gown, value 11s.; 1 bed-gown, value 4s.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; and 4 caps, value 4s.; the goods of
William Withers.

WILLIAM WITHERS, JUN . I live with my parents in Nutford-place, Edgware-road. On the 6th of May my mother gave me a bundle of shirts, and other things, to take to the prisoner's mother, who is a washerwoman—as I was going along, I saw the prisoner lying down on the grass in the fields—he asked me if I was going to his mother—I put the bundle down while I pulled my handkerchief out of my pocket—the prisoner laid his head on the bundle, and then he took it to carry for me—he went into a public-house with it, and told me to stay a minute—I staid, but he did not come out—it was then between two and three o'clock in the afternoon—I went to Mrs. Williams directly—this is the handkerchief the linen was tied in—the pawnbroker has one of the shirts.

SARAH WITHERS . I am the wife of William Withers. I packed up the bundle containing the shirts and property stated—this is one of the shirts which was in the bundle; and this is the handkerchief in which they were tied.

LOUISA CLARKE . I am the daughter of Mrs. Williams, and sister-in-law of the Prisoner. This little boy came to me—I went to the pawn-broker's, where I found the prisoner pawning this shirt, about four o'clock—when he heard my voice he ran out—I ran after him—he was takes in to my sight.

HENRY SWAIN . I am a pawnbroker. On the 6th of May, about a quarter to four o'clock, the prisoner brought this shirt into our shop—the last witness came in to know if we had any linen pawned there—he heard her voice, and ran off—I pursued, and brought him back—he said he did not care, for he wished to be transported; and he had been obliged sleep two nights in the open air.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1319.
JAMES HUMPHREYS,
JEMIMA HUMPHREYS,
JOHN ROWE , and
ANDREW MILLER , were indicted for
a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Second Jury, before Mr. Baron Parke.

div1.p:
1320.
WILLIAM HILL,
ANN SULLIVAN , and
WILLIAM SIMS , were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Parker, on the 5th of May, at West Ham, Essex, putting him in fear, and taking from his per
son and against his will 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-ribbon, value 1d.; 1 watch-key, value 2d.; 1 split-ring, value 2d.; and part of a watch-guard, value 1d.; his goods.

JOHN PARKER . I am a carpenter. On Tuesday night, the 5th of May, I was at West Ham, in company with Charles Firmin—we were at the Unicorn—we went in there about half-past nine o'clock, and stopped about an hour and a half—I saw all the three prisoners there—I did not know them before—I took out ray watch while they were there—it was in my fob—I had a guard to it—I afterwards went to the Swan public-house, at

Stratford, and stopped there not above a quarter of an hour—the prisoners came in after us—Firmin was still with me—I left at twenty-five minutes to twelve—I was rather elevated at this time—the prisoners followed us out of the house immediately—I saw them come out—when I came out, I had my watch in my fob—I observed that—I was perfectly sensible—Firmin and I began larking together—we pretended to be sparring—I took my jacket off, and so did he—I do not know what we did with our jackets—while this was going on, the female prisoner came up, and caught hold of my right-arm, and said I should not fight—my watch was per
fectly safe then, I felt it in my fob—Sims came up close behind me, and I was surrounded by the three; but Sims took me round the body—the other man was close by him, but doing nothing to me—none of them were tipsy—in about a minute I missed the three prisoners—I clapped my hand to my fob, my watch was gone, and my guard cut in two—it was a silk guard—I went to Charles Firmin, and said, "I have lost my watch"—he was about three yards from me—about a minute after Hill came back—I went to him, collared him, and said, "You have stolen my watch"—he said, "No, I have not; so help me God, I know nothing of the watch"—I said, "You know the parties; where do they live? what are their names?"—he said, "I declare I know nothing of the parties; I never was in their company before"—in my fright, I let go of him—I went to a watchman, and told him of my loss; and at four o'clock in the morning, I gave in for
tion to the horse-patrol, and described the-party—they were taken in custody next morning—I recognized them all three—my watch was pro
duced at Lambeth-street office, on the Thursday, by Gutteridge—this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Where did the lark begin? A. Facing the Swan—out of doors—there was only me and my friend there—the prisoners were by themselves—it wanted about twenty minutes to twelve—I live about half-a-mile from the Swan, at Stratford—I had worked for my employer till nine o'clock that evening, and went with Fir
min to the Unicorn, where my master gave us something to drink—we staid there an hour and a half, and then called at the Swan—I left the Unicorn because they shut up the house—we were not turned out—I was not drunk at the Unicorn, but rather high-spirited and elevated—I walked perfectly upright and straight—the Swan is half or three-quarters of a mile from the Unicorn—I had nothing but beer at the Unicorn—I had a glass of gin-and-cloves at the Swan—I took off my jacket about ten minutes after—we had no quarrel at all—I did not mean to fight—it was about three minutes before I missed my watch—there was nobody by but my friend and myself, and the three prisoners, when we were sparring—I was not at all confused with drink—I lost my watch from twenty minutes to a quarter to twelve—the female prisoner took it—I swear that—I have sworn it before—I did not perceive her take it, but she had hold of my arms, and Sims my body—I did not perceive any one take it—I can swear there was no other party with us but the three prisoners—it was done by Sullivan and Sims—Hill was not touching me—he returned, after I missed it, alone—in about a minute he returned to where we were, and said he knew nothing about it, nor of the parties.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. How long were you in the Swan? A. About ten minutes—the prisoners asked us for something to drink there, and I gave them a glass—they did not drink with us—I gave them a glass of gin-and-cloves, the same as I had myself—we had no conversa-

tion with them—Firmin and I were talking together—after we got out, the prisoners came out close behind us—we only sparred for amusement—there was no blow struck—it was not a dark night—I made no blow at him—we had no struggle—I was not down—we did not touch each other at all—here is the piece of my guard.

CHARLES FIRMIN . I am a carpenter. I was with the prosecutor on Tuesday night, the 5th of May—we went to the Unicorn at West Ham, and afterwards to the Swan, at Stratford—I saw the three prisoners at both places; we left the Swan at half-past eleven o'clock, we were sober—the prisoners followed us out—we had a bit of a spar—we did not spar, but agreed to have a spar—both our jackets were off—I did not see the pri
soners come up myself—I had seen his watch twice that evening—once in the Swan, and at the Unicorn—I afterwards saw Sims taken into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q What time did you go to the Uni
corn? A. At past nine o'clock—we drank there till eleven o'clock—I remem
ber Parker taking his watch out at eleven o'clock—we were taking beer there,—we had no spirits at all—I should think I did not drink more than a pot—I will swear I did not drink two pots the whole day—I was not drunk—I can
not say I was sober—I had my senses, and could walk very well, and so had Parker—he was a little elevated; he was a little fresh—we stopped at the Swanabout ten minutes, and had half-a-pint of gin-and-cloves—the prisoners had part of it—they followed us into the house—Parker said he should like to have a bit of a spar—he said he was able to stand against a man as big as a house, in a jocular sort of way—I consented to spar—I did not double my fist—Parker said he had lost his watch, two or three minutes after he came out—Hill was with the other prisoners—they were about a yard off—I did not see the prisoners when we were talking about sparring—not when I was pulling off my jacket—I did not notice how near they were to us at that time—Parker was not far from me—I did not see any thing done to him.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you say any thing to either of the prisoners at the Swan? A. No more than asking them to drink.

SAMUEL GUTTERIDGE . I am a horse patrol. I received information from Parker on Wednesday morning, about four o'clock, and later in the morn
ing I got the particulars from him—I went with him to a house of ill-fame in the Marsh, and found Ann Sullivan, who I knew well before—I brought her out to Parker, and said "I have an accusation against you, for robbing that man of his watch"—she said, "I never saw him—he cannot say so"—I took her into custody; and knowing that Sims lived with her in this house I went in search of him at Old Ford—I told him I apprehended him on suspicion of stealing, Parker's watch—he said, "I know nothing of the watch—I never saw it"—he then said "Charles Firmin said, Parker has got a good watch in his pocket; take it, and I will say nothing about it"—I said I knew Firmin perfectly well, and could not believe any thing of that—I met Hill near Strat
ford the same afternoon—I handcuffed them together, and said to Hill, "I apprehend you on suspicion of stealing this watch of Parker's also"—Sims said "We know nothing of the watch; Firmin persuaded us to take it, and we would not"—Hill said "He did persuade us to take the watch, but we were hard-working men, and we would not take it"—I locked them up in the cage, and next morning Sarah Sims, the prisoner's mother, came to the door of the cage—she had the watch wrapped up in a handkerchief, and gave it to me, after saying something—the prosecutor has identified it—I have frequently seen the prisoners together before.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you tell the Magistrate the conversation you
had with Hill about Firmin? A. No; he said it fn the office when Firmin was giving his evidence—I stated the conversation that I had with Hill when I apprehended him.

SARAH SIMS . I am the prisoner Sims's mother. I heard of this rob
bery about an hour before I was sent for—I heard my son was in trouble—that was on the Wednesday evening on which they were taken—Parker sent for me.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Before you saw your son, did you see the prosecutor? A. No; nor Firmin—Firmin's sister came to my house, and said if I would go to her mother's, where the prosecutor was, I should hear something there—I went there, and saw Parker, and he said if I could get my son to say any thing, he would not hurt a hair of his head, and would go out of the way—I told my son what he had said, when I went to him in the cage.

MR. DOWLING. Q. Had you any conversation with your son in the cage? A. Yes; I afterwards went into the yard of his lodging with the land-lady—there was some dirt in the yard—the landlady moved a little stone—I did not see her take any thing up, but she gave me a watch—it had some
thing black round it—I pointed out where it was to be found—she searched and produced the watch—my son had directed me where to find it—I after
wards gave it to Gutteridge, wrapped in the same black thing, which was quite damp when I received it—the watch could not be seen without mov
ing the stone.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did the female prisoner lire in the same place? A. Yes; I was told so—Firmin's sister said she came from Parker and her mother, to tell me to come, and that her son should not be hurt—that he pitied my case very much, and promised me faithfully he should not be hurt.

CHARLES FIRMIN
re-examined. I gave no advice as to taking Parker's watch—I swear I did not suggest to them to take it.

(John Nuttman, carpenter and builder; Francis Moss; and John Johnson, silk-printer, Oxford-street, gave the prisoner Sims a good cha
racter.)

SIMS—
GUILTY of Larceny only.—Recommended to mercy by the Pro
secutor

and Jury.—
Confined Three Months.

HILL—
NOT GUILTY.—SULLIVAN—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Third Jury, before Mr. Justice Littledale.

div1.p:
1321.
ISAAC DOWSETT was indicted
for that he, having been pre
viously convicted as a common utterer of counterfeit coin, on the 11th of April, at West Ham, Essex, 1 piece of false and counterfeit coin, resem
bling and apparently intended to resemble and pass for a piece of the King's current silver coin, called a crown, unlawfully, unjustly, deceitfully, and feloniously didutter and put off to
Jane Cable, knowing the same to be counterfeit.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant-solicitor to the Mint. I pro
duce a copy of the record of the conviction of Isaac Dowsett, at Rom
ford, in July, 1834—I examined it with the original record, at the office of the clerk of the liberty of—it is a true copy—the record was read to me first, and I afterwards read the record while the clerk read the copy—I examined it with the chief clerk in the office (read.)
SAMUEL SOUTHEY . I am keeper of the prison at Rom ford. I saw the prisoner tried on the 4th of July, 1834, in the Romford Court, for passing

a bad half-crown, and was sentenced to six months' imprisonment in Ilford House of Correction; the last fourteen days solitary—I took him there, and left him there in execution of his sentence—I saw him several times after
wards in the gaol—I remember his being discharged six months after he received sentence.

JANE CABLE . I am a linen-draper, and live at Plaistow. On Saturday evening, the 11th of April, the prisoner came to my shop, about eight o'clock, and asked for a pair of stockings—I gave him a pair at 18d.—he gave me a five-shilling-piece—I gave him 3s. 6d. change—he then went away—I showed it to my mother about five minutes afterwards, but kept it in my possession—I afterwards mentioned it to a person named Fisher—I saw him in King's custody in about an hour, and knew him again—I did not know him before—he had a basket with him when he came and when he was brought back—I gave the five-shilling-piece to King—I know him to be the same person.
JURY. Q. Did you put the crown-piece into a drawer or till? A. No; I kept it in my own possession—I had no other crown-piece.

STEPHEN KING . I am a constable. From information I received on Satur
day, the 11th of April, I went in pursuit of the prisoner—it was a moonlight night—I went in the direction of the iron bridge on the Barking road, and saw the prisoner running about fifty yards from me—I did not know it was him till I got up to him—I called to the man at the gate to stop him, but he did not go on the bridge, but into a stack of osiers—I found him concealed in the stack—I found this basket at the entrance of the osiers, close to the road—it was between two bundles of osiers—I found in the basket a pair of stockings and a loaf, it was about ten yards from him—I asked him if he had bought a pair of stockings at Miss Cable's—he said he had—I said he must go with me to Miss Cable's; and he came with me—he said, "Don't handle me"—he said he dare say if he gave the change back it would be all right—I did not tell him it would be better or worse for him to confess—I took him to Miss Cable's shop with the basket—he said the basket and its contents were his—Miss Cable recognized him directly, and gave me this piece of coin—I have had the care of it ever since—I searched the prisoner at the watch-house, and found a five-shilling-piece and 9s. 6d. on him, all good money—all I noticed that night as the five-shilling-piece—I had 14s. 6d. delivered to me afterwards—I did not take his money from him till I got to Ilford gaol, and I received it from the gaoler.

JOHN FIELD . I am inspector to the Mint. This is a counterfeit crown
piece, made of Britannia spoon metal.

WILLIAM RAYNOR . I am a baker at Plaistow, in Essex. On Saturdays evening, the 11th of April, about eight o'clock, the prisoner came to my shop and asked for a loaf of bread—he paid me a five-shilling-piece—I gave him 4s. 9 1/4 d. in change, four shillings and a sixpence in silver—I put the five-shilling-piece in my pocket—I had no reason to suspect it at that time—I had no other crown-piece in my pocket, nor any silver at all in that pocket—I continued to wear the same small clothes till I went to bed, and wore them again next morning—from what I heard I examined the crown-piece, and thought it was a bad one—I showed it to my daughter—I had it in my hand—I then put it into a drawer by itself—the desk which the drawer was inside of, was locked every night—I put it into the drawer about ten o'clock in the morning, I never meddled with it afterwards—on the 18th of April I directed my daughter to go to the drawer, and she bought me a crown-piece—the desk was not locked during the day—it was

accessible to my daughter during the day, but to nobody else—it is in the parlour adjoining my shop—I have no other children at home—I have servants; they have no business at my drawer—the crown-piece my daughter gave me was a bad one, and the one I had taken on the 11th; this was the Saturday following—I did not see it between that and the 18th—I gave it to King on the 18th—I should know it again—I had not marked it—it is the same in appearance, and appeared to be made from the same base metal.

ELZABETH RAYNOR . I am the daughter of the last witness. On Sun
day, the 12th of April, my father showed me a bad five-shilling-piece—I noticed it, but not so as to know it again—I did not go to his drawer till the Saturday following—I then saw it in a drawer in his desk—I had not seen him put it into the drawer, but I saw it in the drawer on the Sunday morning; almost directly after, he said he had taken a bad crown-piece—I took it out of the drawer on the following Saturday, and gave it to my father—it appeared the same sort of coin as I had originally seen in the drawer—I did not see my father mark it.

STEPHEN KING
re-examined. Raynor gave me a crown-piece, which I produce.

WILLIAM RAYNOR
re-examined. This is the crown-piece I marked and gave to King; it is the coin I took from the prisoner.

ELIZABETH RAYNOR
re-examined. This is the coin I took out of the drawer, and which I saw in the drawer, I believe.
JOHN FIELD . This is a bad crown-piece, and is made from the same mould as the first, and is alike in all respects.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1231.
GEORGE MUNDAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of February, 12lbs. of soap, value 5s.; 8lbs. of bacon, value 3s.; 6lbs. of sugar, value 5s.; and 1 1b. of tea, value 5s.; the goods of
Samuel Lilley, his master.

HENRY DAVID WEST . I was in the service of Mr. Lilley on the 25th of February—the prisoner was his shopman—early that morning, as we were getting up, he asked me to lend him my box; I brought it down stairs, and when I opened the shop, he said, "I wish you would pack these things for me; "and he brought me four bars of soap, the ba
con, and the other things, mentioned in this indictment; he told me they were for himself, and I packed them in my box, as he desired me—he then told me to carry them to Mr. Enever's, a gardener, who lives about a quarter of a mile down the lane—I asked him whether they were set down—he told me they were—I took them, and left them as he desired me, at Mr. Enever's.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. What are you? A. An apprentice. I have been there two years and three months—my time was not out—I left Mr. Lilley in consequence of his suspecting I was engaged in this transaction—he had charged me with pilfering once before—I had given a shilling in change by mistake, and he thought I had done it wilfully—he asked me where the shifting was; I said I did not know; I thought it was in the till—the prisoner and I have been good friends—he never hit me but once—we have quarrelled once or twice—I cannot tell how many times he has scolded me for being lazy, and not attending to my work; but it was not very

often—I never said I would be revenged on him, nor any thing of the kind—I have been to the Coach and Horses; I never lunched there but once—I have been there when my friends have come to see me; they have put their horse there—the prisoner has not said I was doing very wrong to go there so often, and that he was sure I was spending money that was not my own—I came to town with Mr. Lilley, and when we came, be charged me with this, and I was taken to prison for a week—I cannot tell why I was not com
mitted—I did not agree to give evidence against the prisoner at Union-ball—I never denied the charge—Mr. Lilley asked me whether I packed the things up; and I said, Yes, by the prisoner's direction—I was un
der the prisoner's orders—I was not asked if I would come and give evi
dence against the prisoner—I was asked what I knew about it, and stated as I have now, that I acted under hit orders—I was then liberated on bail—I do not recollect that any thing was said to me about giving evidence—I was not in the habit of sending my box to town; I had never sent it—I know Mr. Wiltshire; I never sent my box to him for myself—I had taken a box to Mr. Wiltshire for the prisoner.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How often had you sent this box to town? A. Twice, by the prisoner's direction—I never sent it without.
COURT. Q. Does your master deal in these things? A. Yes; the prisoner brought them to me to, pack up—I asked him if they were put down—he said, "Yes"—my matter was ill at the time.

JAMES ENEVER . I am a gardener, and live at Walthamstow. On the 25th of February the box was brought to my house, but I was not at home—the prisoner came there afterwards—he stopped his horse and cart, and asked the girl for the box—she went to give it him, but could not get it from under the table—my wife asked me to give it into the cart, which I did—Godfrey wat in the cart with the prisoner—the box did not appear to be empty.

GEORGE GODFREY . I am fourteen years old—I remember going with the prisoner to London on the 25th of February—he stopped at Mr. Enever's and said, "Where is that box I am to take to town?"—Mr. Enever gave it him in the cart—we came to town—he drove over London-bridge—he put the horse and cart up, took me further on, and left me at a public-house, and he took the box on his shoulder—I stayed at the public-house three-quarters of an hour—he then came back with the box empty on his shoulder—he gave it to me, and I put it into the cart by, his direction—he told me not to say any thing about his putting the horse and cart up—I afterwards gave the box to Mr. Enever's boy—I had noticed when Mr. Enever gave the box, that it was heavy, for I could not lift it.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever been to London before? A. Yes; but not with the prisoner—never to buy goods for his master—he brought some that day.

SAMUEL LILLEY . I am a tallow-chandler, grocer, and cheesemonger, and live at Walthamstow. The prisoner was in my service, and was dis
charged, on the 27th of February, from something I had heard—I went to an officer, and on Monday the 2nd of March I went to No. 9, New-street, Southwark; the prisoner's wife and child, his mother and brother were there; I saw the officer find this soap; and he took from a closet one piece of sugar, and in a corner of the room he found another piece, of sugar, covered with dirty linen—when the prisoner entered my service he stated himself to be single, and that hu had lived in that character before—I never

doubted it—he came to me on the 20th of October—I had sent him to London on the 25th of February to purchase goods—in going from my house to the lodgings in New-street, it is necessary to go over London or Blackfriars-bridge.

Cross-examined. Q. You would not venture to swear that any of these articles belong to you? A. Yes; I would to the soap—I have sugar here which corresponds with what we found at the lodgings—I can swear to the soap by the make; it is yellow—I had not seen any of the persons I saw at the lodgings before, to my knowledge—I have seen them since, when I was endeavouring to apprehend the prisoner with the officer—there are a great many complexions of soap—this was in a box wrapped in blue paper, and some of the paper adhered to the soap—another tradesman might have put his soap in blue paper, but it should have been a very rare thing that it should be the same coloured paper—the alkali would take the colour out, and put a colour in.

Q. Did not the prisoner offer to give himself up when you spoke to him about this? A. No; I had some suspicion on the Monday after this took place, but not enough to apprehend any man upon—and he came to me to know if I had any thing to say against him, I said, "Munday, I am afraid I shall have"—he promised to meet me at his father's home, in Bishopsgate-street, at three o'clock that day; I went there and waited till nine o'clock, and he did not come—I did not go to town with him at the time he came to me, because I had another person to take, and I wished to search his lodging, though I did not tell him so—I discharged my apprentice also, as I had been in the counting-house and seen him take a shilling, and when I went to look for it, it was not there; but it was explained, and the man came back and brought the shilling, and said, he had it by mistake among the halfpence which he had given him—I had him examined at Union-hall on this business, and he was remanded for another examination, but he was never committed—I did not ask him to come and give evidence against the prisoner, the Magistrate bound him over.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you had some accident? A. Yes; a horse fell with me and knocked my knee all to pieces, the prisoner came to my bed side to receive orders; he was my principal shop
man; the other is only a lad—here is no entry of these goods in the book.
Prisoner. Q. Was I to enter them if they were sold for ready money? A. No.

COURT. Q. Do you permit your servants to pack goods in a box and send them away without booking them? A. No, of course not; I am speaking of the counter-trade; but if such articles as these were sold for ready money, of course the prisoner should book them.

MR. JONES. Q. How long were you ill? A. I think between a fort
night and three weeks, but I used to get down into the room where I could see the transaction of business—my wife was there and my sister—the prisoner had the whole charge of the counter—the apprentice was to clean things, and take things out—he has sold things, but the prisoner was there, and he acted under his direction—I have blamed the prisoner for letting the apprentice serve.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How soon after the prisoner had made an appointment to meet you in London did you take him? A. It was on the 2nd of March he appointed to meet me, and I was not
able to take him till the 20th of April—I was looking for him, and so were the officers of Union Hall.

MR. PHILLIPS to HENRY DAVID WEST. Q. Did the prisoner ever mention New-street to you? A. Yes; in the course of conversation he said his brother lived there—I am quite certain he told me these articles were booked.
Cross-examined. Q. You brought the box down, and packed the goods in? A. Yes; he brought them for me out of the shop—I packed them in the warehouse, on my master's premises.

JOHN NEWCOMBE . I am an officer of Union Hall. I went in search of the prisoner to New-street—I found his mother and wife theft—I found these cakes of soap there and this sugar—the prisoner said before the Magistrate, that the box he brought from Mr. Enever's contained nothing but his own wearing apparel.

Prisoner's Defence. I am entirely innocent—I borrowed the appren
tice's box to take my own things to my mother's, and I brought it back—I know nothing about these things—I gave myself up to Mr. Lilley di
rectly Mr. Wiltshire told me of the charge—my not meeting him at three o'clock that day, was my not seeing Mr. Enever; and the next morning I heard my mother was in custody—I went to a solicitor, who advised me to stay out of the way, which I did; but I did not hide myself—West knows he put the things into the box.
HENRY DAVID WEST . No; I put nothing but the goods into it—there was no black coat, nor any shoes.
JURY. Q. Were you authorised to examine the books? A. No; not after Munday.
SAMUEL LILLEY . West had no authority to examine the books—if he sold any thing he might put it down.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

div0.p:
1322.
PATRICK CARROLL was attainted of the wilful murder of Elizabeth Browning. (See page 14.)

div1.p:
1323.
THOMAS LUTHER was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
John Carr, from his person.
JOHN CARR . I am a carpenter, and live in York-road, Lambeth. I was at Greenwich fair on the 20th of April, and lost a handkerchief, which I have recovered—it is worth 1s. 6d.—this is it.

THOMAS HOBBS (police-constable C 85.) I was on duty at Greenwich fair, and saw the prisoner go behind the prosecutor, and take this hand
kerchief out of his pocket—I seized him instantly with it in his hand—he got it quite out of the pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I picked it off the ground—the policeman called out, "Has any gentleman lost a handkerchief?"—the gentleman turned round, and said, he had—he could not exactly swear it was his at first.

THOMAS HOBBS
re-examined. I saw him take it out of the pocket—he
begged me to let him go, and said, it was his first offence, and that he would go away from the fair.
(Thomas Drew, in whose employ the prisoner had been, gave him a good character, and offered to take him into his service.)

p.hi: Fourth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1324.
FREDERICK BETHELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of April, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
Matthew John Good
son, from his person.

MATTHEW JOHN GOODSON . I was at Greenwich fair, on Tuesday evening, the 21st of April—I lost my handkerchief out of my coat pocket—I did not feel it taken—the officer tapped me on the shoulder, and asked if I missed it, and I did—he produced it at the office at Greenwich—the prisoner was taken up immediately, and admitted taking it out of my pocket—he appeared very agitated, and said hunger compelled him to do it.

ROBERT CLARK (police-constable R 167.) I was on duty at the fair, between ten and eleven o'clock in the evening—I watched the prisoner, and saw him feel in the prosecutor's pocket—after some time he walked away—I asked the prosecutor if he had lost any thing—he said yes, his handkerchief—I went after the prisoner, and drew his hand out of his pocket, with the handkerchief round it—I asked him what handkerchief it was—he said it was his—I said you have just picked this gentleman's pocket of it—he said he had not—the prosecutor said his handkerchief had been bitten by a dog, and had two pieces torn out and darned; and there were those marks—the prisoner said next morning, that he was induced by some boys to do it.
(Charles Bethell, the prisoner's brother, a cabinet-maker; George Jacques, fancy cabinet-maker, Old-street; Henry M'Donald, and Francis Farren, French-polishers, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month.

1325.
ROBERT SPENCER was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
Alfred Henry Maynard, from his person

ALFRED HENRY MAYNARD . I am a butcher. I was at Greenwich fair on the 20th of April—about seven o'clock in the evening there was a great crowd—a policeman said I had my pocket picked, and I found my handkerchief was gone—he pointed the prisoner out, and produced my handkerchief—the prisoner begged for mercy.

DANIEL REARDON . I am a policeman. I was at the fair—I saw the prisoner draw this handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket—he was in company with two boys of his own age—he was putting the handkerchief into his own pocket—I took him with it in his hand.

GUILTY . Aged 13—
Transported for Seven Years.

1326.
RICHARD NEWMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Dawson, from his person.
JAMES DAWSON . I am a carpenter. On the 20th of April I was at Greenwich fair—I felt my handkerchief taken from my coat pocket, while I was in a crowd near Richardson's show—that was knocked off pur-

posely at the time, and then my pocket-picked—my arms were pinioned, but I turned my head round, and the officer had got hold of the prisoner—he asked me if that was my handkerchief; I instantly laid it was, and seized hold of it.
DANIEL REARDON . I am a policeman. I was at the fair—I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket—he was alone—I had seen him in the fair before, and watched him.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me knock his hat off? A. No; I took the handkerchief from his hand, and secured him.

Prisoner's Defence. I and another young man went to the fair to sell four hundred oranges—I took a walk through the fair to have a look at it—I saw two Young lads, one of them had a handkerchief in hit hand; the other said, "D—n that old thing, go and fetch us a tanner"—he threw it down; I took it up—the policeman said, "Give us that handkerchief"—I said, "I shall not"—I did not know he was a policeman; he was in plain clothes—if I had given it to him, he would have said nothing about it.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

p.hi: Third Jury, before Mr. Justice Park.

div1.p:
1327.
HENRY MELLISH was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
William Hogg, from his person.

WILLIAM HOGG . I live in Queen-street, Horsleydown. I was at Greenwich fair on Easter Monday, between two and three o'clock—I did not feel my handkerchief taken—the constable tapped me on the shoulder and showed me my handkerchief—I am sure it is mine—I had been in the fair about three quarters of an hour.

WILLIAM DYKE . I am a policeman. I was in the fair about a quar
ter-past two o'clock, and saw the prisoner following the prosecutor, who had a friend with him—the prisoner was alone—I saw him poll the hand
kerchief about three inches from the prosecutor's pocket at first, and when he got about twelve or fourteen yards further, I saw him take it out entirely—I caught hold of him directly, and he dropped it on the ground—I detained him—there wat not much crowd then—he denied the charge.

WILLIAM HOGG
re-examined. I know the handkerchief to be mine, by a little hole in the middle, and the letters "W. H." in the corner.
Prisoner's Defence. I heard that Mr. Shillibeer wanted an omnibus-man, and went to Greenwich—I wat at the fair, but was never in custody before.

GUILTY .* Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: Third Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabia.

div1.p:
1328.
EDWARD PATTISON was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1329.
JAMES KEITH was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1330.
WILLIAM DIXON and
THOMAS BRAGG were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
John Rouse, from his person.

JOHN ROUSE . I was in the service of Mr. Spottiswoode. I went to Greenwich fair on the 20th of April—I had a pocket handkerchief in my pocket—I did not miss it till the officer tapped me on the shoulder, and asked me if I had lost any thing—this is my handkerchief, it has my mark on it.

JOHN HOBBS (police-constable C 85.) I was on duty in Greenwich fair, on the 20th of April—I saw the two prisoners standing close against the prosecutor, and by seeing their elbows move, I suspected they had drawn a handkerchief—I took them into custody, and saw Dixon throw this handkerchief on the ground; my brother-officer was close by, and I believe he saw the handkerchief drawn—I had watched them for seven or eight minutes.
Dixon. Q. If you saw me draw the handkerchief, why did not you take me? A. I took you directly I saw your elbows move.

JOHN JONES (police-constable S 77.) I saw the two prisoners behind Mr. Rouse—we had watched them before, feeling pockets, and when they went behind Mr. Rouse, Bragg drew this handkerchief, and passed it to Dixon—I seized Bragg, and Hobbs seized Dixon, and that moment the handkerchief fell on the ground.
Dixon's Defence. We were looking at one of the shows—the officer came and charged us with stealing the handkerchief, which I did not see till it was at the station-house.

(Robert Evans, of Slater-street; Thomas Collins, of St. John-street; and Ellen Davis, of Market-street, Finsbury-square; gave Bragg a good character, the latter of whom promised to employ him: and Samuel Desert, of No. 4, Nicholl's-row, gave Dixon a good character.)

DIXON—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

BRAGG—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

1331.
EDWARD TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 2 pewter measures, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Mary Taylor.

THOMAS SEDGER (police-constable R 130.) I was on duty in the Old Kent-road, on the 20th of April—I saw the prisoner, and stopped him, and found this quartern and this half-quartern measure in his right hand trow
sers pocket—I asked what he had got there—he said, "Nothing"—I told him to draw out his hand, which he did—I then found the quartern mea
sure—he said he had got another, and he drew out the other himself—I think he had been drinking.

WILLIAM HARRIS . I am in the employ of Mrs. Mary Taylor, who keeps the Three Tuns, at Greenwich—these measures are her property, and were in use on the 20th of April, in the morning—they have her name on them—the prisoner was taken three miles from her house.

Prisoner. I have no recollection how I got them—I had been drinking—I came up from Manchester, where I used to work in a stable, but the rail-road has destroyed our work so much, that I could get no employ.
THOMAS SEDGER . He said he had been to Greenwich fair, and he was in the road from there.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Weeks.

1332.
JAMES EDWARDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of April, 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 waistcoat, value 5s.; and 2 pair of shoes, value 5s.; the goods of
Peter Jones, Esq., his master.

PETER JONES , Esq. I am a major in the Royal Marines, quartered at Woolwich. The prisoner was my servant for about three months—he ceased to be so on the 23rd of April—I missed some trowsers, a waistcoat, an eye-glass, and other things—I got a search-warrant, and found them at Mrs. Hoafe's, a pawnbroker—I had only missed one livery waistcoat.

Prisoner. When my master found the coats, I told him there were more things, and I gave up the duplicates. Witness. Yes, he did; but, I believe, that was after I had discovered the articles I mentioned.

ROBERT THORNDELL . I am in the employ of Mrs. Hoafe, a pawnbroker. I produce a waistcoat, three pair of trowsers, an eye-glass, and two shirts—the eye-glass, the two shirts, and 1 pair of trowsers, were pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. When did I pawn them? A. The trowsers and eye-glass on the 4th of April, and the shirts on the 9th of April—there was a ring pawned with the eye-glass.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I intended to take them out again, at I expected some money from my father, but before I got it, the Major put me in the guard-house.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.

div1.p: Confined One Month.

1333.
JAMES HESDALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of April, 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of a man whose name it un
known, from his person.

JOHN MURPHY (police-constable G 215.) I was af Greenwich fair, on the 21st of April—I saw the prisoner there in the early part of the day, trying several gentlemen's pockets; and in the afternoon I saw him follow
ing a gentleman—he drew a handkerchief from hit pocket, and put it into his own—I took him, and he drew this handkerchief from his own pocket, and threw it on the ground—the gentleman went off, and I could not tell his name—there was a companion with the prisoner, who escaped.
Prisoner's Defence. What he says is false.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

1334.
JOHN THOMAS was indicted
for stealing, on tke 20th of April, 16 yards of floor-cloth, value 3l. 4s., the goods of
James Cobbett.

JAMES COBBETT . I am a floor-cloth manufacturer, and live at Deptford
bridge, Greenwich. This floor-cloth is my property—I lost it on the 20th of April—it is worth about 3l. 4s., at the wholesale price.

CHARLES CHAPMAN . I am a miller, and live at Brixton. I was passing the prosecutor's shop on the 20th of April, between seven and eight o'clock, and I saw a boy with his hand on the floor-cloth—he said to the prisoner, Why don't you come on?"—I went across to my cousin, and I saw the other boy try to put it on his shoulder—it slipped down, but he took it up again—I then lost sight of him—I crossed, and my brother had got the prisoner with it on his shoulder.
WILLIAM CHAPMAN . I was passing with my brother—I saw a boy take up this floor-cloth, and drop it again—he then took it up and put it on the prisoner's shoulder—I ran and stopped him with it.
HENRY PRICE (police-constable R 56.) The prisoner was given into my custody—I asked if he knew any thing about the floor-cloth—he said he took it from the shop, another boy gave it him.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

1335.
JOHN SULLIVAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of April, 3oz. weight of cigars, value 3s. 9d. the goods of
James Thorne.

MARIA RIDER . I am the wife of Richard Rider, a carpenter, and live in Park-row, Greenwich. I saw the prisoner come out of Mr. Thorne's shop on the 21st of April, with something wrapped up in a sort of hand
kerchief—I informed Mr. Thorne, and called, "Stop thief"—I followed the prisoner, and I came up to him—I saw some cigars on the ground when he was stopped—I gave him in charge.

SARAH THORNE . I am the wife of James Thorne, a tohacconist, in Park-row, Greenwich. On the morning of the 21st of April, my attention was called to this by Mrs. Rider—I examined the box, and missed a great many cigars—they were worth 3s. 9d.—those produced by the officer ap
pear to correspond with what I lost—there is nothing particular about them.

THOMAS GIBBONS . I am in the employ of Mr. Lackington, at the Plume of Feathers, in Greenwich. I was at the top of East-lane on the morning of the 21st of April—I heard an alarm of" Stop thief"—I went after the prisoner, and found some cigars down by his feet, when he was stopped.

WILLIAM KIRBY (police-constable R 186.) I was on duty on the 21st of April—Mrs. Rider gave the prisoner into my charge—I produce the cigars which were handed to me—they were not wrapped up then—I found some fragments of cigars on him, and 2s. and a halfpenny.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming by a street, and picked up a paper with some cigars in it; I put them into my pocket—a man came and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined One Month.

1336.
CATHERINE GREENY was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of April, 3 spoons, value 2l., the goods of
Sophia Amelia Bradley, her mistress; and
JOSEPH PIEARS
for feloniously receiving the said goods, well knowing them to have been stolen, against the Statute.

SOPHIA AMELIA BRADLEY . I am a widow, and live in Thornton-row, Greenwich. The prisoner, Greeny, was my servant—I missed some table-spoons on the 22nd of April—I spoke to her about them—she had complained of being ill, and was going away on the Saturday—I said I should wish the policeman to question her, and told her to leave her box, and come again on Monday—these are my spoons.

ELIZA ALLEN . I am the servant of Mrs. Bradley—Greeny was her cook—I missed the table-spoons, and told my mistress of it—I then spoke to the prisoner—she said she did not think they were right, but she knew nothing about them—I have seen Piears at the door, speaking to her, and I recollect his coming to the house on the Friday in the Easter-week—I saw the spoons safe last, on Easter Sunday—I missed them the next morning.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you at church on Easter Sunday? A. Yes; I was absent about two hours—my mistress was out also—Greeny was left at home—Piears kept company with her—he might have been in the house while I was at church—the spoons were kept in the parlour—I had seen him twice at the house speaking to Greeny—he might have gone into the parlour where the spoons were.

JOHN ADAMSON (police-sergeant R 1.) On the 27th of April I went to Mr. Carter, a pawnbroker, and found these spoons there—I saw Greeny at Mrs. Bradley's in the afternoon—I asked her if she knew any thing about any silver spoons—she said no she did not—I asked her if she had any young man came to see her—she said yes, a young man named Piears, who lived at Chelsea, but she could not tell where—I apprehended him in the Magistrates' room while the case was proceeding against Greeny.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he come to the room? A. No; he was brought by another constable.

EDWARD CARTER . I am a pawnbroker at Greenwich—I produce these table-spoons, which were pawned with me on the 20th of April for 1l. by the prisoner Piears—I asked him whose they were—he said his father's.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know him before? A. No—there were several other persons in the shop, perhaps half a dozen—it was not par
ticularly busy day—there was no other shopman there—there might be 150 persons come to the shop in the course of the day—I suppose there were not half a dozen of them strangers—I asked the prisoner the neces
sary questions, and he gave his name as Richard Grant, George-street.

ELIZA ALLEN
re-examined. There were two young ladies left in the house with Greeny when I and my mistress went to church—I did not see Piears at all that day.
NOT GUILTY .

1337.
WILLIAM WARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d. the goods of
John Vyse Kelly form his person.

JOHN VYSE KELLY . I am a clerk in the Government Life Annuity Office—on the 20th of April I was at Greenwich fair—I felt a tug at my pocket, turned, and saw my handkerchief in the prisoner's hand—the officer took it from him.

JAMES ANDREWS (police-constable M 45.) I was in the fair about one o'clock, and saw the prisoner following the prosecutor very closely—I watched him for a minute or two—when they got opposite Richardson show I saw him take the handkerchief, and collared him.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to the fair to try and get work—I was getting through a crowd when the officer took me.

GUILTY .* Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1338.
JOHN CARTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 22d of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
Edward Hollis, from his persorn.

EDWARD HOLLIS . I am a farmer, and live in Huntingdonshire. On the 22d of April I was at Greenwich fair—I had a handkerchief fn my pocket—I did not know it was taken, till I was touched on the shoulder—I then looked back, and saw it in the officer's hand—this it—I had it safe in my pocket when I went into the fair.

JAMES WILD (police-constable R 141.) I was at the fair—I saw the prisoner with two or three others—I watched them, and saw the prisoner take this handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket—I took him with it in his hand, while he was endeavouring to pass it to another.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not have it in my hand—I was pushing
through a crowd after my father—I saw it on the ground, and the officer took me.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months and
Whipped.

1339.
THOMAS SHEPPARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
William Rhodes, from his person.

WILLIAM RHODES . I live upon my property, in Claremont-place, Old Kent-road. I was at Greenwich fair on the 20th of April—I went into a booth, but did not miss my handkerchief till I was told of it—this is it.

JAMES WILD . I am a policeman. I was at the fair, and saw the pri
soner sounding several gentlemen's pockets, about twelve o'clock at night—at last he went behind the prosecutor, who was listening to a song—I saw him walk suddenly away—I went and asked the prosecutor if he had lost any thing—he said, yes, his handkerchief—I told him to go with me, and we found the prisoner blowing his nose with the handkerchief—I took him, and found on him these snuff-boxes, this other handkerchief, these cigars, and cases.
Prisoner. I had not the handkerchief—it was at my feet—I had been in a booth—this man came and took me, and took the handkerchief up from my feet.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1340.
MARY ANN ASHDOWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 2 coats, value 2l.; 1 pair of breeches, value 10s.; and 1 pair of gaiters, value 5s.; the goods of
George Gayton Palmer.

GEORGE GAYTON PALMER . I am a captain in the Royal Artillery, at Woolwich. I have a servant named Joseph Ashdown, who is the husband of the prisoner—I had a pair of breeches, some gaiters, and two coats, which he wore—I cannot say when I had seen him wearing them, or whether he gave them to the prisoner—he went into the hospital on the 31st of March, and on the Sunday following I received information, and the prisoner left my kitchen, where she had been allowed to live with her husband—I saw her at my quarters between the 31st and the Sunday—I cannot say whether, during that time, she resided in the kitchen—she might have done so if she pleased.
LEWIS DAVIS . I am a pawnbroker. I have one coat which I took in of the prisoner, in—the name of Mary Wright, on the 2nd of April.

THOMAS PACEY BIRTS . I am a pawnbroker. I have a coat, a pair of breeches, and a waistcoat, pawned by a person in the name of "Ann Pol
lock, for William Smith, it was not the prisoner."

MARY WRIGHT . I am the wife of Benjamin Wright. I was sent for by the prisoner on the 4th of April, to Captain Palmer's quarters—she asked me to take this suit of clothes to the pawnbroker's—I told her I never made a practice of taking things there—these are the clothes, or like them—a young woman named Ann Pollock took them, and got 30s. on them.
Prisoner. I did not ask her to pawn them, but another person did—I was in distress, and pawned them thinking they were my husband's, and that he would get them out again.
NOT GUILTY .

1341.
THOMAS SAVAGE was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of April, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
William Thomas Allen, from his person.
WILLIAM THOMAS ALLEN . I am clerk to a solicitor, at Woolwich. I was at Greenwich fair on the 22nd of April—I had this handkerchief then in my pocket—I do not know who took it.

JOHN MURRAY (police-constable K 178.) I was at the fair. I saw the prisoner and another close behind the prosecutor—the prisoner started off, my brother officer caught him, and gave him to me—I took this handker
chief out of his bosom—he said, "I did it, for I was in want."

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1342.
WILLIAM JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief value 2s., the goods of
William Drew Phillips, from his person.

WILLIAM DREW PHILLIPS . I lodge at Lambeth. On the 20th of April 1 was at Greenwich fair—an officer came, and told me I had been robbed, he desired me to follow him, and be would point out the person—we went and found the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand—the officer took it from him, this is it—it has my mark on it.

RICHARD TOZER (police-constable R 149.) I was at the fair, and saw the prisoner there, about nine o'clock in the evening—I followed him till half past ten o'clock at night—he tried several gentlemen's pockets, and then he went behind the prosecutor, and took his handkerchief out—I told the gentleman of it, and we went and took the prisoner, with it in his hand.

Prisoner. I was going from the fair between nine and ten o'clock, and saw two boys drop the handkerchief; I took it up, and before I had got two yards, the policeman came and said I had stolen it. Witness. I swear I saw him put his hand into the prosecutor's pocket and take it—I found on him a snuff-box, with some scented snuff in it.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1343.
THOMAS CHAPMAN and
JAMES CREASY , were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of April, 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Christopher Dunkin Francis, from his person.
ANN BROOKS . I am servant to Mr. Christopher Dunkin Francis. This handkerchief is like his, and it is marked with his name—to the best of my belief it is his—he is now at Oxford.

THOMAS HOBBS . I am a policeman. I was at Greenwich fair on the 20th of April. About five or six o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the two prisoners in company, standingclose behind Mr. Francis—I saw Chapman put his hand into his pocket, and take out this handkerchief; he was in the act of handing it to Creasy—I took them both into custody—the prosecutor followed me to the station—he stated before the Magistrate that his name was Christopher Dunkin Francis.
Chapman. We picked it up. Witness. I saw him take it out, and I had watched them sounding pockets for half an hour before.
(Mary Grace, of Harp-alley, gave Chapman a good character.)

CHAPMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

CREASY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1344.
JOHN WILLIAMS, alias
JOHN GOING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May, 13 shirts, value 10s., the goods of
Benjamin Baxter; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1345.
GEORGE MOOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 7 pounds of ham, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Hollis.

THOMAS HOLLIS . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Church-street, Woolwich. I had a piece of ham in my shop on the 9th of April, which weighed seven or eight pounds; I missed it the next morning—the watch
man afterwards showed it to me—this is it.

JOHN NOYES . I am a watchman, at Woolwich. About eleven o'clock at night, on the 9th of April, I stopped the prisoner with a bundle, and asked him what he had got; he said his own property—I desired him to open it, and I saw it was part of a ham—I told him to come to the watch-house—he called out, "Jones," Jones then came across the way—I said to him, "Jones, I know you, and if you offer to rescue him, I will have you to-morow;" he then kept back—the prisoner and I had a scuffle—I threw him down—I saw the errand-cart going by, and I called the man; he said he could not leave his cart, but he would take the bundle, which he did—I then had my hands at liberty, and the prisoner went pretty quietly to the watch-house.
WILLIAM SMITH . I received this ham as I was going by in the errand-cart—I gave it to Chittenden.
WILLIAM CHITTENDEN . This is what I received.

Prisoner. On the day the ham was lost, I was passing the shop, and picked it up nearly opposite the window—I tied it up in this handker
chief, and was going towards Charlton, when the watchman took me; it was through distress that I kept it, or else I would have taken it into the shop.
MR. HOLLIS. The ham might have dropped down, but I do not think it did. It was in a box where we put them to show; but they cannot fall down.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

1346.
JAMES MCCRAUSKIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of April, 1 quilt, value 10s.; and 1 counterpane, value 10s.; the goods of
Richard Morsley.

RICHARD MORSLEY . I am a tailor, and live in High-street, Woolwich. I had a counterpane and quilt, hanging in my garden to dry on the 23rd of April—I cannot say when they were put out; but I saw them at seven o'clock in the evening, and they were afterwards missed—these are the articles—the back of my premises adjoins a skittle-ground.

JOHN ALSFORD . I went to the prisoner's father, in Red-lion-street—I found the prisoner there, and accused him of being concerned in this robbery—he said he knew nothing about it—I took him to the cage, and the officers fitted his shoes to some marks on the ground.

CHARLES STEWARD WARDEN (police-inspector.) I took the prisoner's shoes off, and fitted them to some marks in the ground—one of the shoes has no iron on the heel; the marks in the ground so entirely correspond with his shoes, that I have no doubt the shoes made the marks—there were other marks besides—I went to the prisoner's father at eight o'clock in the morning, and found both these articles in the back premises.

Prisoner. About six o'clock I went to the public-house to have a pint of beer; one of the persons there said, "Come, and have a game of skittles;" we played—I then came in again, and had another pint or two of beer—I left there about half-past eight, and went to another public-house, and had some more—the place where these things were found is a thoroughfare. Witness. It is a back-yard, but his father had the key of it—there is an open space between the pales and the wall, and these things were pushed in there.

Prisoner. Whilst we were playing at skittles one of the boys threw the ball into the prosecutor's ground, and I got over the gates to get it—at two o'clock in the morning they took me out of bed—they searched the same place, and did not find these articles. Witness. We did not look in that, place at that time.

GUILTY .* Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1347.
JAMES ELLIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, 8 yards of printed cotton, value 6s.; 2 yards of calico, value 1s. 6d.; 1 yard of linen cloth, value 1s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 5s.; 2oz. of ham, value 2d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 18d.; the goods of
Elizabeth Collis, from her person.

ELIZABETH COLLIS . I am in the service of Dr. Gregory, at Woolwich. On the 7th of April I was walking along, and the prisoner came up to me—he told me not to be frightened—he walked with me, and wanted to carry my umbrella—I told him to go away, bat he would not—he took hold of me, and I screamed, "Murder"—he let me go, but he took my bundle which I had, it contained the articles stated—I am sure the prisoner is the man—I had not seen him before.

Prisoner. There were no shoes in the parcel—I received it from a comrade of mine, who was discharged the same day—I did not take the parcel from her. Witness. I am sure he is the man who took them from me—it was quite moon-light, and between nine and ten o'clock in the evening.

JAMES MORRIS . I am a watchman. On the morning of the 8th of April, I went into the New-road, Woolwich; and saw the prisoner with a bundle under his arm, I asked what he had got there—would he allow me to look at it—he said, "Certainly"—I found it was the articles which this young woman lost on Woolwich Common—he said, a man named Jemmy gave him the things, that he went with him to the Gun public-house, had a pint of beer, and there Jemmy went away and left the bundle with him—the prisoner was in the Artillery, but was discharged the day this was committed—the young woman was brought to see him, and said, she knew him again by his whiskers—I tried every means to trace where he slept that night, but could not—he was sober, and smoking a cigar; he went backwards and forwards by a clothes-shop, where they buy and sell articles of this kind.

Prisoner. I had been in the hospital three months—and when I got out, a little liquor which I took had an effect upon me, and I cannot tell where I slept, but I found myself in a passage, and these things, were there—I took them up, and this man took me with them.

MARY LEE . At a quarter-past ten o'clock that evening I heard a cry of "Murder"—I saw the prosecutrix, who appeared very much frightened—I saw a soldier run across the road and fall down—he got up and looked
round, and took up the bundle and went away—I could not swear who he was.
Prisoner's Defence. I had received this bundle from a comrade who had been discharged the day before, and gone off in the steamer.

ELIZABETH COLLIS
re-examined. Q. How far had you walked with him? A. Nearly a quarter of a mile; he asked me to go down a lane—I was not so frightened as to be mistaken in the person—I am sure he is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined One Year.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1348.
CAROLINE TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of April, 1 tea-caddy, value 1s.; 1 shaving-box, value 1s.; 1 tinder-box, value 1s. 6d.; 3 brushes, value 2s.; 1 cotton-box, value 1s.; and 2 sovereigns; the goods and monies of
Ezekiel Johnson.

EZEKIEL JOHNSON . I am a West Indian. I am steward of His Ma
jesty's ship the Thunderer—I was ill and invalided—I came round to take my pension—I meant to retire to Plymouth—I had bought some things for my own use—on the 25th of April I fell in with the prisoner at Green
wich—I do not know the name of the street, for I was a mere stranger—I met her in the afternoon—I could not say whether she first spoke to me or I to her—I was looking for a lodging, and she said she could help me to one—I went home with her to a room up one pair of stain, where there were two beds—two persons were in one bed before we went in—I did not know who they were—I did not look into that bed at all—there was a spare bed for us—the prisoner and I went to bed together—I went in first—I undressed—I had two sovereigns in money, besides my bundle of goods, which had in it a tea-caddy, a shaving-box, a tinder-box, and the other articles stated—the sovereigns were in a little bag that hung to my neck next my skin; they were there when I went to bed—I had paid the pri
soner some money; I do not know how much—I think our agreement was for 5s.—I paid her before, and I paid for the bed before I turned in—we went to bed between nine and ten o'clock—I fell asleep, and in the morning, when I awoke, the prisoner was gone, and all my things, and the money that had been tied round my neck—the man who had been in the other bed was gone, but the woman was there, and she is here now—I should not have known the prisoner's name but for this woman—I went for an officer, and gave him a description of my goods—I saw the prisoner again the next day (I think) before the Magistrate—I am sure she is the person.
Prisoner. You never gave me a farthing. Witness. Yes, I did—they would not let me have the lodging till I paid the money—I gave her 5s., and paid 1s. 6d. for the bed.

THOMAS JUDSON . I keep the Red Lion, at Greenwich. The prisoner gave me these articles to take care of for her, on the 25th of April—they were tied up in paper, and I gave them to the constable—she told me to take care of them, and let no one have them but herself, and she would call the night after—it was between five and six o'clock in the morning.
Prisoner. Q. Did not the parcel contain a tea-caddy and a cotton-box? A. I do not know; it was wrapped up in a paper.

SOPHIA STANHOUSE . I know the prisoner. On the 25th of April I slept at my own lodging with a young man named Powell—there were two beds in the room; the prisoner occupied the other bed—I knew nothing about the prosecutor being there till I awoke about three o'clock in the morning,

when the prisoner and he were in the room; I got up, and asked Powell to give me money to get something to drink; he gave me 4d. to get a pot of beer, and just as I was going out at the door, the prisoner said, "Will you bring me something in?" I said, "I don't mind"—I was gone three quarters of an hour, because the door was not open, and when I came back I saw Powell was up and dressed—I said to him, "What are you up for, you had better go to bed, it is too soon to get into the barracks—he said, "No; come and have something to drink"—I went with him, and the pri
soner came after us—we were going on the way to Woolwich, and, just as we got by the White Horse, she pulled out her glove and said, "I have got two sovereigns which have not been changed"—we told the policeman.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see the two sovereigns? A. No; but she said there were two sovereigns in the glove—when I went out in the morning, she gave me the halfpence to bring her a quartern of gin.

WILLIAM DAVIS . I am an inspector of police. About nine o'clock in the morning, on the 25th of April, I received information from the last witness that a sailor had been robbed, and they were in the eating-house—I went, and found the prisoner and a marine with her—I found 15s. on her, and 6s. 7d. on him—I took them to the station-house, and then went to the prosecutor, who said he had been robbed.
Prisoner. Q. When you came to me did I deny any thing? A. No; you threw the glove down, and I found a crown-piece, four half-crown-pieces, and 4 1/2 d. in copper, in the glove.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor bought these things for me at a hard
ware-shop—he told me to choose what I liked—he gave me no money—I did not ask for any, as he had bought me the things—the witness got up, and went out for some beer—she did not return, and we went to look for her—the marine went with me—the officer came into the public-house which we went into, and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1349.
JOHN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a man unknown, from his person.

JAMES WILD . I am a policeman. On the 20th of April, I was at Green
wich fair in plain clothes—I saw the prisoner, and several others sounding people's pockets—I at last saw the prisoner take this handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket—I took him, and asked the gentleman if the handker
chief was his—he said it was—he went to the station, but refused to give his name and address—I do not know who he was.

Prisoner. While I was in a crowd looking at a show, I felt the handker
chief at my feet—I took it up, looked at it, and put it into my pocket—the officer then came up in plain clothes, and I thought it was his—he took me to the gentleman, who was ten or twelve yards off—he said it was his—but he would not prosecute as I had not done him any injury.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1350.
JOHN GREEN and
WILLIAM SUTTON were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a man unknown, from his person.

DANIEL REARDON . On the 21st of April, I was on duty in Greenwich fair, about six o'clock in the evening—I saw the two prisoners in company to
gether—I watched them, and saw them follow a gentleman and two ladies—

Sutton drew the gentleman's handkerchief from his pocket—Green followed close to him with his hand on his shoulder—I took hold of Sutton, and he threw the handkerchief from his trowsers—I touched the gentleman, and said, "Have you lost any thing?"—he said, "No, I do not think I have," but he felt, and missed it—a crush then came on, and I lost the gentleman and ladies, but I kept Sutton—Green said that Sutton should not go with me, but I got him out of the crowd, and Green followed me down to the watch-house—I found these two snuff-boxes on Sutton—I do not know the gen
tleman's name.
Green's Defence. I asked him what was the matter—I followed him down to the station, and he said he would take me as one of the gang.

Sutton's Defence. I was standing, looking at a show, the officer came and took me, and asked the gentleman whether he had lost his handker
chief—he said, "No" several times over—I was then taken; but I never had the handkerchief in my possession.

SUTTON—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

GREEN—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1351.
JOSEPH PIEARS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 3 spoons, value 2l., the goods of
Sophia Amelia Bradley.
(The evidence in this case was the same as that given in the case of Greeny and Piears, page 190.)
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1352.
WILLIAM MARSH and
GEORGE DIXON were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Drayton, from his person.—2nd COUNT, stating it to belong to a man unknown.

JAMES WILD . I am a police-officer. I was at Greenwich fair, on duty—I saw the two prisoners following a gentleman; and Dixon drew this handkerchief from his pocket, while he was going into a booth—I took them both into custody, and found this handkerchief and another on Marsh—I had seen Marsh sound the gentleman's pocket, and he said to Dixon, "You go in"—I followed them into the booth, and saw Dixon take the handkerchief—the gentleman went to the station-house with me, and gave his name as John Drayton—he stated that he was a barrister, of Lincoln's Inn—I have not heard of him since—I do not know his name except from what he said.
Marsh's Defence. I had nothing to do with picking the gentleman's pocket; I was five or six yards away from him.
(Joseph Price, an Upholsterer, of Crown-street, Finsbury; George Swan, a chair and sofa-maker; and John Meredith, a carver; gave Dixon a good character.

MARSH—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

DIXON—
GUILTY. Aged 12.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Six Days.

1353.
JAMES KEY and
THOMAS SHEARMAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of April, 1 handkerchief, value 5d., the goods of
Daniel Mahoney, from his person.—2nd COUNT, stating it to belong to a man unknown.

JAMES WILD (police-constable R 141.) I was on duty at Greenwich fair, on the 22nd of April, between two and three o'clock I saw the pri
soners and another person in company—I watched them, and saw Key go behind a poor man, and take this cotton handkerchief out of his pocket, he passed it to Shearman, who put it in the flap of his trowsers—I told the man he had lost his handkerchief—he said he had—I told him to come with me—I took him about five yards, and took the two prisoners—I opened the flap of Shearman's trowsers—I gave the other one to the pro
secutor, but he got away—the prosecutor followed me to the station, and gave his name as Daniel Mahony—he stated that the handkerchief was his.

KEY—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

SHEARMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Nine Months.

div0.p: 1354.ANN TUTHEY was convicted of larceny (see page 20.)

p.hi: Fourth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1355.
CHARLES BABER was indicted
for feloniously and burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Cox, at St. Saviour's, Southwark, about the hour of twelve in the night of the 22nd of April, with intent to steal.

THOMAS COX . I live at No. 107, Union-street, St. Saviour's, South
wark, and am a shoemaker—I have another establishment in the New-cut—the prisoner was formerly in my employ for six or seven weeks. On the 22nd of April, I met him with George Rogers, who had been in my employ—I went to a public-house with them—I went to one or two pub
