lic-houses with Rogers, and to one with the prisoner—I had something to drink, and was a little intoxicated—it might be about eight o'clock in the morning when I met the prisoner—I left the company of Rogers, went home, and went to bed between twelve and one o'clock, as near as possible—I do not think I was in the prisoner's company above an hour and a half, but I was with Rogers till about half-past twelve o'clock in the day time—I left him close by my own home—I was in bed at one o'clock, and slept through the day and the night; and about a quarter to one o'clock in the morning I was awoke by my dog barking—I was certain there must be somebody in the shop, by the barking of the dog which was in the shop—I was quite sober at this time—when I came down, I saw the prisoner in the shop—I had the gas burning—I gave an alarm backwards—I sung out, "Murder! thieves!"—I could see nobody in the shop but the prisoner—I was quite sure he was there—I was not the first person who got into the shop—I called out backwards, seeing the prisoner in the shop—while I was calling out, Mrs. Cox jumped out of bed, and flew into the shop—we got the street door open, and gave an alarm there—I sent my boy, Jenkins, with some goods to the other shop, in the New-cut, next day, and on his return he made communication to me.

COURT. Q. When you saw the prisoner in the shop what became of him? A. He made his escape through the same place as he had got in at—I found the shutter lying down in the middle of the pavement—I am sure it was the prisoner—he got out through a stall under my window, where I have two men working.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was this on Easter Wednes
day? A. Yes, or Thursday—I went to bed in the middle of the day on Wednesday—I was not much in liquor on Tuesday night—I was a little intoxicated on Wednesday at one o'clock, which made me go to bed—I was not at home on Tuesday night—I was walking about, not a mile from home—I was not at all the worse for liquor—I met the prisoner and Rogers about eight o'clock, as near as I can say—I believe I was drinking—I was not the worse for liquor when I met them—I was not in their company on Tuesday—I was at home principally the whole day.

MRS. COX. I am the prosecutor's wife. On Wednesday the 22nd of April my husband came home and went to bed—he remained in bed the whole day—I shut up, and went to bed between eleven and twelve o'clock—Jenkins, my boy, left at ten o'clock—before I went to bed I saw every place secure—I looked at the window-stall shutter—I saw it was fastened—the window-slides and the shutter-bolts—at one o'clock in the morning Mr. Cox awoke me, as the dog awoke him—he called out and said there were thieves in the place—I immediately jumped up, and ran into the shop—I saw the prisoner—he was the only person I saw in the place—he went down into the stall, and got out—I saw no more of him—I opened the street door and hallooed out "Thieves" and "Murder"—the policeman came very soon after, and he went down—I saw the bolt of the shutter next morning almost broken in two—the prisoner could get out, as the stall-shutter was unbolted—the street door was quite safe, as I had left it, bolted with two bolts and locked—he must have come in through the stall.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you first learn from your husband that you were to be a witness? A. I was sent for about an hour and a half ago—I was not before the Magistrate—I can swear to the prisoner—I was nearer to him than my husband was—my husband was quite sober that night, but in the middle of the day he was a little drunk; but not so that he could not stand, and was obliged to go to bed—I did not charge Ro
gers with having been on the premises; but I understand he was accused—I cannot tell where my husband was on Tuesday.

MR. DOANE. Q. Whether Rogers was in the shop before you got there you cannot tell? A. No; the dog had seized the prisoner, and that awoke us—I did not see the dog seize him, but he made a sad noise when he came towards our bed-room.

JOHN JENKINS . I am in the prosecutor's service. On Wednesday, the 22nd of April, I went on an errand for my mother, after leaving my master's to the Monument public-house in Union-street, about twenty yards from Mr. Cox's premises—I saw the prisoner and Rogers there, and two girls with them—the prisoner asked me if my master was at home—I said, "What is that to you? Yes, he is"—Rogers then asked me if my master was in bed and asleep—I said yes, he was—this was rather before eleven o'clock at night—I had left my master's at ten o'clock—next day I was sent by my master down to the New-cut, and on the road I saw Rogers with two other girls, by the side of Mrs. Slater's shop, where the prisoner works—I overheard a conversation between Rogers and the girls, and informed my master—I saw the prisoner in Mrs. Slater's shop on my return.
NOT GUILTY .

1356.
JOHN CLARE was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of April, 1 pair of half-boots, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Isaac Rose; and that he had before been convicted of felony.

ISAAC ROSE . I am a salesman, and live in Tooley-street. On the 16th of April, between five and six o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner put his foot on my step, and reach these shoes, which hung over the door
way—he ran off with them—I pursued—he threw them away—I knew him well before, and did not trouble myself about him then, but gave information to a policeman, who took him the next day—I am posi
tive he is the man—I picked the shoes up.
JOHN WATERS . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner, and have the shoes.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN CHRISTIE . I am a policeman. I have a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office (read)—he is the man who was convicted—I was a witness on the trial.
Prisoner. I know nothing about the charge.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

p.hi: Second Jury, before Mr. Justice Park.

div1.p:
1357.
JOHN TUCKER was indicted
for burglariously breaking and en
tering the dwelling-house of
Samuel John Davis, about the hour of twelve in the night of the 22nd April, at St. Mary, Lambeth, Surrey, with intent to steal, and feloniously and burglariously stealing therein, 1 looking-glass and stand, value 4s., his property.

SAMUEL JOHN DAVIS . I live at No. 46, White Hone-street, Cornwall-road, New-cut. It is in the parish of Christchurch, I think—I do not pay taxes—I sometimes sell fish, and sometimes fruit—I do not rent the house, it is let out in tenements—I am a lodger—the landlord does not live in the house—I have one room to myself, separate from the other lodgers—on the 22nd of April, between eight o'clock at night, and one o'clock in the morning, this happened—I locked my room-door at eight o'clock, and was absent from eight till one o'clock—my wife was with me—we went towards Greenwich fair—when I went away, I left the prisoner sitting on the steps, outside my door—I am quite certain I locked the room-door—we returned between twelve and one o'clock in the morning—I found my room-door open, and missed a looking-glass off the drawers—I knew the prisoner before, by his brother being with me—he lived nearly opposite to me—I got a constable and went after him, and found him in bed—he lives with his mother, who is a widow—I told him I had lost the glass—he denied it—I took him to the station-house in Tower-street, and after the Inspector put a few questions to him, he said he had taken it, and sold it to a woman named Rogers, for 4s.—I went to her house, and found it there.

ELIZABETH ROGERS . I live in White-horse-street, near to the prose
cutor. On the night of the 22nd of April, at a quarter-past nine o'clock, the prisoner came to my house, and asked if I would buy a glass of his mother, for she was in distress, and wanted to past with it—he wanted 4s. for it—I said I had not got 4s.—I gave him 2s., and said I would give him two more on Saturday night—the policeman came to my house about one or two o'clock in the morning, and I gave the glass up to him—I am sure he is the boy who sold it to me.

WILLIAM BOND . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner in charge, and to the station-house—the Inspector said, he must go before a Magistrate in the morning"—as he was going to be locked up, he turned round and said,

"Sam, I did take your glass"—the prosecutor said, "What did you do with it?"—he said, "I sold it to Rogers, No. 51, White Horse-street"—I went and took Mr. Rogers into custody—the prisoner said it was not him but his wife; and I went to the woman, and got the glass—I have had it ever since.

SAMUEL JOHN DAVIS
re-examined. I went out about twenty minutes to nine o'clock that night—it was not quite dark—it was light enough to distinguish him on the steps, and know him.

ELIZABETH ROGERS
re-examined. He came to me at a quarter after nine o'clock—I was just going to bed—I had got a candle—it was light enough to see about the house just before.

GUILTY of Stealing only. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor, on account of his youth. —
Confined One Month, and
Whipped.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1358.
THOMAS FARRER was indicted
for embezzlement.

GEORGE RICHARD GAINSFORD . I live in the Borough. The prisoner was in my employ for nearly two years—he was occasionally employed to collect money—on the 4th of April he received 20s. from my partner, Mr. Charles Goode—he was to purchase some stair-rods.

ROBERT HALL WRIGHT . I am in the employ of the prosecutor—the prisoner came to me before he went out, and he had an I. O. U. for 4l. of me—he afterwards brought me this bill for 3l. 5s., and 15s., which made the 4l.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When was this? A. On Saturday, the 21st of February—the I. O. U. is a piece of paper with those letters on it—I have not got it here; Mr. Farrertore it up—I gave him three sovereigns, and 1l. of silver, of Mr. Gains ford's money—there are thirty-six people in our shop—I give other persons money when they are going out—I can
not say how often—when they are going out with goods they come to me for cash for change—I entered what I gave the prisoner in the book, but it is not here—the prisoner brought me 15s. and this bill for 3l. 5s.—I put my initials on it, but they are partly torn off—I cannot swear that this is the bill he brought me, but it was a bill for 3l. 5s.—I put my initials at the Town-hall, about eight weeks after he had the money—I had not seen the bill from the time he gave it me, till I was at the Town-hall—I had given it to my master.
COURT. Q. The prisoner brought you a bill on the 21st of February, for 3l. 5s.? A. Yes; he did not bring me a bill of that amount from Mr. Phillips on any other day.

GEORGE RICHARD GAINSFORD
re-examined. Q. Do you recollect giving the prisoner any directions about getting the goods? A. He told me he was going to get some rods—I did not give him the order—that was on the 20th or 21st of February—there had been several purchases of rods about that time—I had possession of this bill—it was given me on the 21st of February, or the day following, as we balance every morning—if the 21st was Saturday, I received it on the Monday morning—I had no other bill from Mr. Phillips amounting to 3l. 5s.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you keep the bill till it was produced at the Town-hall? A. Yes, it was part of the time in the cash-box, and the rest of the time in the desk—we purchased from the same person both be
fore and afterwards, but not to the same amount—here is another bill, which is 19s., from the same person.

JOSEPH PHILLIPS . This is my bill and my writing—I sold these articles to the prisoner—I gave this receipt for the amount which I received from the prisoner—he requested me, after paying that bill, to make out a second bill, as they were to sell to a customer, and they did not want him to know that they got a profit on them—I said it was not usual, but I did it—my demand was 2l. 15s., but the second bill was 3l. 5s.—I received only 2l. 15s.—the original bill was made out in the name of Gainsford; the second without a name.

Cross-examined. Q. Is this your hand-writing, "Paid J. Phillips," to the time 3l. 5s.? A. It might be another transaction I am speaking of—he had several transactions, the same articles, and the same quantity—I cannot swear that I gave this bill and receipt.

Q. What did you mean by saying you received 2l. 15s. and gave a bill for 3l. 5s.? A. That must be a previous transaction—I sup
pose on the date of this, I received 3l. 5s. of him—I suppose so by the receipt, because I never receipt a bill without I receive my money—I re
ceived 2l. 15s. for a bill, and made the bill 3l. 5s., but I cannot say on what day it was.

JURY. Q. Is it usual to give a retail and a wholesale bill? A. I did so, as I knew Mr. Gainsford had a list of my prices—as to the dales, I can say nothing about them—according to this, I did receive 3l. 5s.—I do not know what the goods would amount to, as I have not my books here.
NOT GUILTY .

1359.
WILLIAM HARDING was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of April, 1 counterpane, value 6s.; 1 bed-cover, value 7s.; 5 pillow-cases, value 3s.; 10 towels, value 3s.; 2 table-cloths, value 7s.; 1 mull, value 5s.; and 1 brooch, value 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Edward Savage, his master.

EDWARD PERKINS . I am foreman to Mr. Savage, a pawnbroker in Paradise-street, Lambeth; the prisoner was in his employ for fifteen months—I spoke to Mr. Savage, who sent for an officer—I went up stairs and searched the prisoner's box—the prisoner had the key of it, and either he or the officer opened the box—there was a counterpane, a bed-cover, five pillow-cases, and some other things, they belonged to Mr. Savage, and have my own marks on them—the prisoner first said he had them of Mr. Jones; he afterwards said he had them at our house, and he meant to pay for them—there is no entry of them in our books.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Were there many other things in the box? A. I cannot rightly say, they were mixed with other things—I think these things did not fill the box—I do not know that it is usual for pawnbroker's men to wear brooches which belong to their master—the prisoner was confused.
THOMAS EDWARD SAVAGE . These are my property—the officer found them in the prisoner's box.
Cross-examined. Q. How long had he been in your service? A. About fifteen months, we had a good character with him.; had no reason to complain till latterly.
GEORGE WILSON (police-constable L 162.) I was present, and saw these things found.
JURY to EDWARD PERKINS. Q. Was the prisoner's box in the shop? A. No; in the warehouse—the sale-shop is down stain, he had 20l. a year, and his board and lodging.
(Samuel Hunt, a tailor, of Seymour-place; Richard Jones, a coal-
dealer; Mary Ann Wallis, a widow; Lucy Fairbrother; and William Marden, a stationer, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Trans
ported for Seven Years.

1360.
JAMES JOHNSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of February, 720 yards of patent linen, value 1l. 18s.; and 72 yards of patent sash-line, value 12s.; the goods of
James Watson, his master.

JAMES WATSON . I am a patent sash-line maker, and live in King-street, Southwark. The prisoner was in my employ—these are my lines, I can swear to them by the make and the materials—my stock is large, and I could not miss them—the prisoner had no right to sell any.

HENRY ADOLPHUS FISHER . About two months ago I bought three parcels of sash-line of the prisoner—he said he made them himself, and served Mr. Monk, in Church-street, Bethnall-green, and that he had been travelling a long way—I made inquiry, and there was no such person—he came again about a fortnight ago, and I had him taken.
JOHN BLAZE (police-constable M 145.) I was sent for, and took the prisoner—this is the property.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 24.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p: Confined Three Months.

1361.
CHARLES FREDERICK BUTLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of March, 10 sovereigns, the monies of
Elizabeth Ann Wood; and that he had been before convicted of felony.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the monies of
Michael Wood.

ELIZABETH ANN WOOD . I live with my father, in Bermondsey-street. On the 25th of March the prisoner came to my lather's, dressed as a sailor; be introduced himself as Edward Butler, and said be had just arrived from Sidney, in New South Wales, and that he was chief officer of the ship Australia—he asked if Mr. Wood was at home; I told him he was not—he said he would have given the world to have seen him, as it was on par
ticular business—he said so repeatedly—he then said, "You have some friends there, "and mentioned the name of a friend we had there some years back; but I do not know whether he is there now—he mentioned the name of Undershaft—I asked if he had any message from him; he said, as I was a female, he could not tell me, but it was very particular business—he then asked for a bit of paper, and wrote upon it "Mr. Edward Butler, chief officer of the ship Australia, East India Docks"—he gave me the paper—I said I had heard of the name—he said, "Yes, you know the family"—I said, "I know Miss Butler"—he said, "Yes, Harriet Butler"—he then mentioned the names of several friends, and appeared perfectly acquainted with them—he then asked me if I would give him a glass of beer; I said, "Certainly"—my sister then came in, and asked him to walk in—he went and sat nearly an hour—he said could not I send for Miss Butler?—I said I could; he said, "Say Mr. Butler has arrived from New South Wales"—he said, if Mr. Wood had been at home, he should have gone with him to his ship—he said, "He should have gone in my gig; I suppose you know what that means, My jolly-boat"—I said he would not have gone—he said, "Yes, he should have slept in the same bed that Justice Stevens slept in"—he said, "We brought them over, and put them on shore at Penzance"—he said,

"I shall be up on the ship's business at half-past six o'clock in the morning, and then Mr. Wood must go with me to the Custom-house" he said he should have his uniform on, and I should scarcely know him—he then mentioned the name of Edgington, and some friends at Seven Oaks, and said he had got some things on board for us, which he would give us if we liked them—he said he had some sparrows, and ajar of tamarinds, which were quite genuine; and a parrot of very beautiful plumage—he dare say I had never seen one so beautiful in my life—he said, "What do you suppose we can get them for?"—I said I did not know—he said, "We can get them for a common handkerchief because they are not allowed to use money"—he staid some time, and then said, "Can you oblige me with 5l.—I said, "Certainly"—as I was counting that he said, "If you have five more, I shall be much obliged to you"—when I was counting down the remainder, I said, "Is it to change a note or a cheque?"—he put his hand on it directly, took up the ten sovereigns, and said, "I shall be back in half-an-hour, when Miss Butler will be here;" and I understood him he should return it—whether he said that or not I do not know—it rather confused me at the moment—he went away immediately, and I never never saw him again till he was in custody.

Prisoner. I asked for the loan of five sovereigns, and wished to see her father—she asked if I was a relation of Mrs. Butler's. Witness. No; I have stated the truth—he said, "Will you oblige me with five sovereigns."
COURT. Q. Did you understand that you were to lend it to him? A. No, I expected he would come back immediately, or within half-an-hour.
Prisner. Q. Did you not ask me if I had a cheque? A. No; I said, "Is it to change a cheque?" and you said, "No"—I was too much alarmed, or I would have sent for an officer.
COURT. Q. When were you alarmed? A. When he put his hand on the money, and took up the sovereigns—he said what I have stated, and left immediately.

MICHAEL WOOD . I have merely to say this was my money, which I had intrusted my daughter with, when I was out on business—I had no rea
son to expect any thing from any body in that country, and I have not re
ceived any thing.

GEORGE MURRAY . I know the prisoner; his name is Edward Delves—I produce a copy of his conviction in Surrey, which I got from Mr. Law
son—I was present at the trial, and know he is the man (read.)

Prisoner's Defence. I certainly went and asked if Mr. Wood was at home—she said he was not—she asked if I was related to Mr. Butler; which I am, as Mr. Butler in Cheapside married my sister—I said, "Can you oblige me with five sovereigns?" and she produced a bag in Which were forty or fifty sovereigns—I said, "Can you oblige me with five more?"—she said "Yes"—I took the money, and did not return.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1361.
ELLEN MAGUIRE was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1362.
ELLEN DEMPSEY was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1363.
CORNELIUS DONAGHUE was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of April, 5 shawls, value 25s., the goods of
John Shayler.
SAMUEL WITHERS —I am in the employ of Mr. John Shayler, who lives in the Borough—on the 25th of April, at a quarter before nine o'clock, I was in

the shop—I saw the prisoner and a lesser lad at the window—I heard a con
versation between them; the lesser lad said to the prisoner, "See, we can nail these shawls"—there were some shawls inside the shop, and they were looking in at the door—I looked at them—they saw me, and went away—I stood outside the counter for about twenty minutes—I then turned my back, and heard a cord snap—I saw the shawls disappearing round the window—I ran out and saw the prisoner throw these shawls down—I ran up a yard next to our house and saw the prisoner; I collared him, and brought him back with the shawls—he begged to be forgiven—these are the shawls.
JOHN HOLEHAN (police-constable M 90.) I took the prisoner, and have the shawls.
Prisoner. I had occasion to turn up the archway, and some gentleman came and took me to the shop; and as we were going in, this witness came out of the shop, and said, "That is one."
SAMUEL WITHERS . No; he was running up the yard when I took him myself, and brought him back—I can swear he dropped the shawls, but he was some distance from them when I took him.

GUILTY . † Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1364.
ELIZABETH GINN was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of May, 1 watch, value 10l.; 1 watch-ribbon, value 2d.; 1 watch-key, value 8s.; 5 half-crowns, 6 shillings, and 3 sixpences; the goods and monies of
John Couchman.

JOHN COUCHMAN . I was in High-street, Southwark—on the 2nd of May, as near twelve o'clock at night as possible, I met the prisoner—she asked me to go with her—I said I did not mind, and asked if she was going far—she said, "No, a very little way"—she took me up a court, which I find is Chapel-court—we went to a house, and went to bed—I awoke about two o'clock, the prisoner was gone, and I missed my watch and the silver, which was in my pocket—I was sober—no one had been in the room to my knowledge—I had fastened the door when we went to bed—I had some half-crowns, six shillings, and three sixpences, in my poceket, which I lost—I had in a secret pocket 73l., but that was all safe—after some search we found the prisoner—I am sure she is the person—I have not seen the watch since.

Prisoner. He gave me half-a-crown, and I went with him—I was there an hour, and then I left and went home—it was half-past two o'clock before I went, away—about four o'clock in the morning the officer came and took me—the prosecutor said he had lost his watch and 15s.—the room door was left open when I went down stairs—he was not sober. Witness. I bolted the room door when I went in, and put the watch under the pillow.

WILLIAM BOWMAN . I am an officer. I saw the prosecutor about two o'clock in the morning—he was quite sober—I went to a house in Kent-street, where I found the prisoner in bed with three others—I awoke her up, and said she most go to the station-house—I searched the other three, and the place, but could not find the watch—the prisoner denied it then but in going along she said she had had it, but had not got it.
Prisoner. I said I had the watch, and put it under the pillow.

JOHN COUCHMAN
re-examined. I work in the wine-trade in general, but am in want of a situation—the 73l. was sent me from the country—I gave the prisoner the watch to put under the pillow.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE 15TH.
